msItem.explicit: fol. 122ra Maneat semper nobiscum dilectus. qui si quandoque uel ad tempus nobis recedat. reuertatur ad nos uelociter. Quod nos prestare dignetur⸵ qui est benedictus in secula Amen.

msItem.incipit: De sollicitudine gloriose uirginis iesum duodennem querentis.
msItem.explicit: Partim moralis partim allegorica fol. 122va exposicio eius quod scriptum est. Surge aquilo ueni auster perfla ortum meum. et fluant amomata illius.

msItem.rubric: De solicitundine gloriose uirginis. iesum duodennem querentis. Capitum primum.
msItem.incipit: In lectulo meo per noctes quesiui quem diligit anima mea. Quesiui et non inueni illum. Surgam et circuibo ciuitatem per uicos et plateas quaeram quem diligit anima mea? Quaesiui illum⸵ et non inueni. Inuenerunt me uigiles⸵ qui custodiunt ciuitatem. Num quem dilexit anima mea uidistis? Paululum cum pertransissem eos⸵ inueni quem diligit anima mea. Tenui eum. nec dimittam. donec introducam illum in domum matris mee. et in cubiculum genetricis mee. Song 3:1–4 Cum nuptiarum sollempnitates festiue celebrantur. dum ad iocunda leticie spectacula hyllariter concurritur. relegari procul debent tristicia. planctus. et meror.
msItem.explicit: fol. 167vb Opem nobis conferat dilectus noster iesus noster⸵ qui est benedictus in secula amen.
fol. 168ra Quedam semplex explanatio trium predencium clausularum.

msItem.incipit: De assumptione gloriose uirginis. et de legatione gabrielis archangeli ad eam missi.

msItem.explicit: fol. 211va Quod igitur malis compleri desideramus. in nobis compleat iesus cristus dominus noster. cui honor in seculorum secula Amen.

msItem.rubric: Incipit .vi. liber de assumptione gloriose uirginis et legatione gabrielis archangeli ad eam missi.
msItem.incipit: Quid uidebis in sunamitem nisi choros castrorum. Song 7:1 Legitur hester fuisse formosa ualde et incredibili pulchritudine. omnium oculis graciosa et amabilis.
msItem.explicit: fol. 257vb Supplico igitur mater salutis. amor mundi. celorum delicie⸵ ut pro me misero. misericordie mater intercedas ad dominum nostrum iesum xpistum filium tuum. cui laus et honor et imperium⸵ per infinita secula seculorum amen.

msItem.note: An offset imprinted on the lower board indicates that an opening from a liturgical book was formerly used as a pastedown, written in a protogothic script, probably from the eleventh century.

supportDesc.foliation: Foliated 7–257 (two labelled 253), in ink, using medieval form of Arabic numerals.
supportDesc.collation: First gathering is missing, which presumably consisted of six leaves (or possibly eight, if the first two pages of the gathering were left blank). a2, 1–298, 30–3110 The leaves of many gatherings are lettered to designate their order, with an additional symbol (e.g. a line above) to distinguish the gathering. Most catchwords have been trimmed away, but can occasionally be seen in ink at the foot of the final page of the gathering, in the right-hand corner (e.g. fol. 166v).
supportDesc.condition: Metal pin in upper board is corroded and has worn through pages in first gathering.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet; pricked on outer edges for frame and individual lines. Line spacing 6 mm. Double rules in centre of each margin, used for aligning marginal headings and other annotations.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic textualis, first half of the thirteenth century; at least three scribes.

decoDesc.decoNote: New books open with initials integrating images of animals, decorated in gold leaf (on fols. 52v, 84r, 122v, 168r, 211v). New chapters open with two-line Arabesque initials, alternating between red and blue, with penwork in the opposite colour. Titles to chapters and marginal headings rubricated. Paragraphs between with an enlarged capital alternating between red and blue. Sentences begin with a slightly bolder capital. Initials not executed beginning at fol. 224r; rubrication not completed beginning at fol. 252v.

additions.p: Text corrected by a contemporary scribe, with changes integrated in most cases. Annotations by readers from the fourteenth, fifteenth, and sixteenth centuries. Drawing of a head on fol. 148r in crayon.
Pressmarks: ·A·162· (spine, Bury St Edmunds, 14th cent.); Th. N 4 8, (2716) Bod. 670., Ms Med. 117 Bod. 356 (fol. 7r).

binding.p: Gothic binding, whittawed leather over oak boards, . Blue and white endbands. Some metal pins remaining from a missing clasp and chain.
binding.decoNote: On spine, Alexander nequam super cantica (14th century).

history.origin: Written in the middle of the thirteenth century at Bury St Edmunds Abbey. Listed there by Leland: Richard Sharpe et al., eds., English Benedictine Libraries: The Shorter Catalogues, Corpus of British Medieval Library Catalogues 4 (London: British Library, 1996), B16.13. For contextualization of the pressmark, A.162, see Richard Sharpe, ‘Reconstructing the Medieval Library of Bury St Edmunds Abbey: The Lost Catalogue of Henry of Kirkstead’, in Bury St Edmunds: Medieval Art, Architecture, Archaeology, and Economy, ed. Antonia Gransden, Conference Transactions 20 (Leeds: British Archaeological Association, 1998), 204–18.
history.provenance: Given by William Smart to Pembroke College, Cambridge in 1599; Thomas James, Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis (London, 1600), no. 152.
history.acquisition: The Summary Catalogue indicates that the book arrived at the Bodleian between 1613 and 1620.
